metadata.sermon_start_end: Parables are intended to interrupt our settled practices. They are addressed to people who have it all settled and figured out who are now invited to think again. [...] The present arrangement among us of the rich man and the poor man is unsustainable. It is, before our very eyes, “coming to ruin.” This is a time, says Jesus, for reversal! The story makes me wonder what the rich man should have done to make the story work differently. I wonder about that. What do you think the rich man might have done differently?
metadata.liturgical_context: Sixteenth Sunday after Pentecost, Year C
metadata.historical_context: The sermon references the racial crises in Charlotte and Tulsa (2016) and mentions Donald Trump's rhetoric, placing it in the mid-2010s American socio-political context.
metadata.notes: The sermon exhibits a strong prophetic-rhetorical style characteristic of Post-liberal homiletics.

criterion_a1_imagery.analysis: The imagery is grounded in the biblical text's own vividness, which the preacher amplifies through contrast. The 'purple and fine linen' of the rich man is sharply juxtaposed with the 'bodily sores' and 'stench' of the poor man. The preacher utilizes sensory details—hunger, high fevers, cooling tongues, and the 'dark nether world'—to make the parable's reversal palpable. While the imagery is not always 'original' in a poetic sense, it is highly effective in its 'cinematic' quality, as Paul Scott Wilson advocates. The preacher 'paints' the scene of the chasm and the 'bosom of Abraham' not as abstract theological loci, but as physical spaces of embrace or exclusion. The imagery serves the 'reframing' of reality by making the invisible poor man (Lazarus) the only one with a name and a face, while the rich man becomes a nameless 'type'.
quotes: His body was covered with sores; he had no health coverage. He was endlessly hungry.
The image is the poor man being welcomed and embraced by Father Abraham... in the bosom of Abraham.
Send Lazarus to dip the tip of his finger in water and cool my tongue; for I am in agony in these flames.
strengths: Strong use of contrast between luxury and misery.
Effective 'naming' of the poor man to restore dignity.
Sensory appeal to thirst and heat in the depiction of Hades.
improvement_points: Could incorporate more contemporary sensory metaphors for 'wealth' beyond the biblical text.
The 'dark nether world' could be more vividly described to avoid traditional clichés.
More 'showing' of the rich man's daily feast would heighten the 'telling' of his greed.
criterion_a1_imagery.show_vs_tell_balance: The sermon leans toward 'showing' the biblical scene but 'telling' the contemporary application.

criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.analysis: The language is exceptionally precise, reflecting Marilyn Chandler McEntyre's 'stewardship of language'. The preacher avoids 'Canaanite' jargon, instead using sharp, contemporary terms like 'health coverage', 'social loser', 'mogul', and 'rigged system'. This precision prevents the message from being lost in pious generalities. The word choice is deliberate—using 'entitlement' and 'vulnerability' to categorize the characters. The preacher nuances the theological concepts of 'Abraham' (grace) and 'Moses' (obedience) without resorting to dry dogmatics. Every word serves the purpose of 'interrupting' the hearer's settled practices. The language is 'loving' in its justice-oriented approach, seeking to do justice to the 'nameless' by naming them.
quotes: He was a poor man who did not show up regularly for work, who did not pay taxes, who was not productive in any way.
The rich man... is a type for all 'lovers of money' who ate and dressed well to the neglect of the poor man.
Abraham signified unconditional love. Moses represented uncompromising covenantal obedience.
strengths: Excellent translation of ancient categories into modern socio-economic terms.
Avoidance of religious clichés through the use of sharp, secular vocabulary.
Nuanced distinction between different biblical traditions (Abraham vs. Moses).
improvement_points: The phrase 'get his ass in gear' might be jarring for some liturgical contexts, though rhetorically effective.
Occasional use of 'everyone knows' can be a rhetorical shortcut that lacks precision.
Could further define 'wicked' beyond the lack of Torah obedience for a secular audience.
criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.jargon_analysis: Religious jargon is almost entirely absent; theological terms are redefined through the lens of social reality.

criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.analysis: The sermon has a distinct rhetorical cadence, characterized by parallelism and repetitive structures ('Who knew? Who would have thought it?'). The sentence length varies effectively—short, punchy sentences for emphasis ('They both died.') followed by longer, explanatory periods. There is a palpable 'staccato' in the descriptions of the rich and poor, creating a rhythmic tension that mirrors the 'chasm' in the text. The use of the 'Abraham/Moses' dialectic creates a balanced, almost symphonic structure in the middle section. It is clearly 'oral language' designed to be heard, with a natural flow that builds toward the prophetic 'ruin' of the wicked.
quotes: Who knew? Who would have thought it? One would expect he had long-term health coverage.
The poor man died and was picked up by angels. The rich man died and was buried.
Abraham signified unconditional love. Moses represented uncompromising covenantal obedience.
strengths: Effective use of rhetorical questions to engage the listener.
Strong rhythmic parallelism in the comparison of the two men.
Natural oral flow that avoids the 'paper language' of academic lectures.
improvement_points: The transition to the contemporary political section (VI) feels slightly more 'prose-heavy' and less rhythmic.
Could use more alliteration or assonance to make key phrases more memorable.
The ending is somewhat abrupt, losing the rhythmic momentum built in the middle.
criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.paper_language_diagnosis: Exclusively oral language; the text is a script for a performance, not an essay.

domain_a_poetics_of_language.summary_language: The poetics of this sermon are characterized by a 'sober-prophetic' beauty. It eschews decorative metaphors for sharp, diagnostic language that bridges the gap between the 1st and 21st centuries. The imagery is cinematic and text-driven, while the precision of word choice (stewardship of language) prevents the sermon from becoming a sentimental cliché. The rhythm is that of a seasoned orator—repetitive, questioning, and balanced. It is a language of 'interruption', designed to break through the 'settled' ears of the congregation through clarity and rhythmic force.

criterion_b1_narrative_arc.analysis: The sermon follows a masterful 'Homiletical Plot' (Lowry). It begins by 'upsetting the equilibrium' with the claim that parables interrupt settled practices. The 'conflict' is established through the wealth gap. The 'turning point' (climax) is not just the death of the characters, but the theological reversal of Abraham and Moses. The energy does not drop; it intensifies as the preacher moves from the biblical story to the national economy and racial crisis. The movement from 'then' to 'now' is not a leap but a steady progression. The conclusion avoids a 'happy ending', instead leaving the hearer with an open, haunting question that sustains the tension of the 'chasm'.
quotes: Parables are intended to interrupt our settled practices.
But then, in verse 9, the song reverses field in a terse verdict: The way of the wicked he brings to ruin.
What do you think the rich man might have done differently?
strengths: The theological 'reversal' (Abraham for the poor, Moses for the rich) serves as a powerful structural pivot.
Maintains tension until the very last sentence.
improvement_points: The section on Psalm 146 (V) feels slightly like a 'detour' that slows the narrative momentum.
The transition to the racial crisis could be more organically woven into the 'Moses' section.
The 'escape hatch' comment is clever but could be integrated more smoothly into the final appeal.
criterion_b1_narrative_arc.plot_diagnosis: A dynamic journey from 'settled practices' to 'socio-economic interruption'.

criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.analysis: This is the sermon's greatest aesthetic strength, embodying Cilliers' 'reframing'. The preacher does not just 'apply' the text; he allows the text to 'frame' the contemporary world. The 'rich man' is reframed as the 'mogul of CBS' or the beneficiary of 'white privilege'. The 'poor man' is reframed as the victim of 'payday loans' and 'cheap labor'. The synthesis is organic because the preacher identifies the 'ideology' behind both the biblical and modern contexts. The 'strangeness' of the text (the reversal of Abraham/Moses) is used to challenge the 'familiarity' of our economic assumptions. It is a profound 'inter-esse'—standing between the ancient word and the current racial/economic crisis.
quotes: The rich man reminds me of William Paley, mogul of CBS. It is said that he is the only one whose will began, 'If I die . . .'
Everyone knows that the gap is not an accident... sustained... by a rigged system of tax laws.
We are not fooled by the long history of white privilege at the expense of cheap black labor.
strengths: Surprising and natural connection between 'lovers of money' and modern tax/labor laws.
The 'Abraham/Moses' dialectic provides a sophisticated hermeneutical key for context.
Honors the 'strangeness' of the biblical reversal.
improvement_points: The mention of Donald Trump is highly context-specific and might date the sermon quickly.
The jump to Charlotte and Tulsa is powerful but could benefit from one specific 'image' or 'story' from those events.
Could address the 'middle class' hearer who might not feel like a 'mogul' but still participates in the system.
criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.reframing_present: The sermon offers a radical new frame: grace is for the 'losers' and law is for the 'winners'.

criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.analysis: Following Stark's 'open work of art', the sermon is polyvalent. While the preacher's political stance is clear, the *theological* ending is remarkably open. By ending with a question ('What do you think the rich man might have done differently?'), the preacher invites the hearer to become an active participant in the meaning-making process. It avoids the 'kitsch' of a pre-chewed moralistic solution. However, the socio-political analysis is quite 'closed' and assertive ('Everyone knows...'), which might create 'resistance' (Stark) in some hearers. Yet, the 'space for grace' remains open because the preacher acknowledges the 'key tension' and leaves the final 'action' to the hearer.
quotes: The story in Luke is only a parable. That is all; not more.
What do you think the rich man might have done differently?
It is, then, for us to act this out.
strengths: The ending is a classic 'open' invitation to reflection.
Acknowledges the parable as a 'story' rather than a dogmatic blueprint.
Leaves room for the hearer to struggle with the 'Abraham/Moses' tension.
improvement_points: The 'Everyone knows' rhetoric can feel coercive and 'close' the space for those who disagree.
Could offer more 'ambivalence' regarding the difficulty of changing systemic structures.
The 'wicked' vs 'righteous' dichotomy in the Psalm section is quite monovalent.
criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.open_work_diagnosis: A 'prophetically open' work: the diagnosis is firm, but the response is left to the hearer.

domain_b_dramaturgy_of_structure.summary_structure: The macro-aesthetics of the sermon are built on a 'reversal' dramaturgy. The structure is not a static three-point sermon but a narrative arc that moves from the 'settled' world of the rich man to the 'interrupted' world of God's future. The integration of text and context is seamless, utilizing 'reframing' to make the biblical characters contemporary actors in the American economy. While the political rhetoric is sharp, the homiletical structure remains an 'open work' by concluding with a question that forces the hearer to step into the 'chasm' and decide their own path.

kitsch_diagnosis.analysis: The sermon is a powerful antidote to religious kitsch. It refuses 'cheap comfort' and 'happy endings'. There is no sentimentality here; the 'sores' of Lazarus are not romanticized, and the 'torment' of the rich man is not smoothed over. The preacher avoids the 'kitsch' of immediate reconciliation, instead sustaining the 'agony' and the 'chasm'. By assigning 'Moses' (hard law) to the rich and 'Abraham' (grace) to the poor, the preacher subverts the usual kitschy religious formula where the 'successful' are God's favorites. The emotion is authentic because it is rooted in the 'pain of suffering' and the 'sternness of justice'.
examples_of_kitsch: None present; the sermon actively deconstructs the kitsch of 'easy grace' for the wealthy.
Avoids the 'clichéd story' of the rich man repenting at the last second.
authentic_moments: The description of the 'nameless' rich man vs the 'named' Lazarus.
The refusal to resolve the 'chasm' at the end of the sermon.
kitsch_diagnosis.recommendation: Maintain this 'anti-kitsch' stance by continuing to resist the urge to provide 'three easy steps' to fix the wealth gap.

space_for_grace_analysis.analysis: The sermon creates a 'Space for Grace' (Cilliers) specifically for the 'unqualified' and 'undeserving'. It opens a space where the 'social loser' is embraced by Abraham. However, it simultaneously 'closes' the space of self-sufficiency for the 'lovers of money'. This is a 'Reformed' aesthetic: grace is not a general atmosphere but a specific, 'reframing' event. The mystery of God's 'unconditional love' is respected by showing its 'astonishing' nature. The tension between 'Abraham' and 'Moses' is sustained throughout, preventing the sermon from becoming a purely moralistic 'to-do list'.
space_for_grace_analysis.tension_sustained: The tension between grace (Abraham) and law (Moses) is the central axis of the sermon and is never collapsed.
space_for_grace_analysis.mystery_respected: The mystery of why God chooses the 'loser' is upheld as a 'surprising future'.
space_for_grace_analysis.moralization_vs_grace: Grace prevails for the poor; Moses (law) is used as a diagnostic tool for the rich. It avoids 'moralizing' the poor.
space_for_grace_analysis.recommendation: To open even more space, the preacher could explore the 'vulnerability' of the rich man (addressed as 'child' by Abraham) as a potential site for grace.

overall_aesthetics.summary: This sermon is an aesthetically robust example of 'Prophetic Reframing'. It excels in its ability to take an ancient, often-sentimentalized parable and transform it into a sharp, diagnostic tool for contemporary socio-economic reality. The poetics are characterized by 'stewardship of language'—using precise, non-religious terms to 'interrupt' the hearer. The dramaturgy is dynamic, moving with a clear arc from 'settled' assumptions to 'interrupted' futures. It is a 'sober-Reformed' aesthetic that finds beauty not in baroque decoration, but in the 'sober beauty' of truth-telling and the 'power of metaphor'. The sermon is a model of 'anti-kitsch', refusing to offer cheap comfort to the 'entitled' while opening a radical 'space for grace' for the 'disregarded'. Its primary aesthetic achievement is the 'reversal'—of names, of traditions (Abraham/Moses), and of futures.
strengths_top_3: Profound 'Reframing' of the biblical text within the contemporary economic and racial context.
Exceptional 'Stewardship of Language' that avoids jargon and hits with precision.
Masterful 'Anti-Kitsch' stance that sustains the tension of the 'chasm' and the 'sores'.
improvement_points_top_3: The 'Everyone knows' rhetoric could be softened to invite more 'polyvalent' engagement from skeptical hearers.
The transition to the Psalm section could be more structurally integrated to maintain narrative momentum.
The contemporary political references (Trump, Charlotte/Tulsa) could be balanced with more 'timeless' sensory imagery.
overall_aesthetics.comparison_with_specialists: Johan Cilliers (Reframing/Space for Grace) and Paul Scott Wilson (Imagery/Four Pages).
overall_aesthetics.audience_analysis: Aesthetically appeals to 'socially conscious' hearers and those weary of 'religious kitsch', though it may provoke 'resistance' in those identified as 'lovers of money'.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Experiment with more 'showing' of the 'bosom of Abraham' to deepen the aesthetic of grace.
Try to find the 'vulnerability' in the 'villain' to see if grace can penetrate even the 'chasm'.
Continue to use the 'open ending' as it is your strongest structural tool.
overall_aesthetics.conclusion: The sermon is an aesthetically high-quality 'event' (Immink) that successfully 'reframes' reality. It avoids the pitfalls of 'religious kitsch' and 'paper language', offering instead a 'performance' of the biblical text that is both ancient and urgent. While its prophetic edge is sharp—perhaps 'closing' space for those it critiques—it ultimately serves the 'beauty of simplicity' by restoring a name to the nameless and a future to the hopeless. It is a 'strong' (7.8) homiletical work that demonstrates how form and content are inseparably connected in the service of the Word.
